Issue #21 Mitsubishi Pajero Evo 2006 L. Alphand/G. Picard

For the first time in its history, the Dakar started in Portugal in the capital city of Lisbon. The rally continued through Morocco, Mauritania, Mail, Guinea, and Senegal for a total of 2991 miles of special stages.

Once in Africa, the expected battle between Mitsubishi and Volkswagen started setting up with a clear advantage to the Japanese brand immediately after entering Mauritania. But title-holder Stéphane Peterhansel, who seemed untouchable in the sand, hit a tree in stage 12 giving his teammate Luc Alphand his first stage win. Alphand, who remained at the same level of excellence all along the event, claimed 2 stage wins and his first Dakar: a winning switch for the former alpine skier.

Norev La Légende Du Dakar #21 Mitsubishi Pajero Evolution MPR12 2006 Dakar Rally Winner L. Alphand/G. Picard

Purchased: 2009

Only win for Luc Alphand
11th Dakar win for Mitsubishi
11th Dakar win for Pajero (only win for Pajero Evolution MPR12)

Mitsubishi Motors made history in 2006 when Luc Alphand & Gilles Picard won the Dakar Rally, claiming a record-breaking 11th overall victory and 6th consecutive win for the Japanese manufacturer on this legendary rally. The outright success was the first for Alphand - runner-up in 2008 and a former World Downhill skiing champion - and the second for his French co-driver Gilles Picard, who had won the Dakar with fellow countryman Jean-Pierre Fontenay in 1998.

Alphand & Picard took the outright lead between Bamako in Mali and Labé in Guinea, when former multiple winner Stéphane Peterhansel crashed into a tree and damaged his rear suspension and transmission. Despite fierce pressure from second-placed South African driver Giniel de Villiers, Alphand took few risks over the closing three days of the 15-leg event to record a winning margin of 17 minutes and 53 seconds after the final timed section near Dakar was cancelled.
